speaker: ellenosborne
content: Thank you, Kate, for starting this conversation. To answer your question, when we say "during instructional time," we're referring to any period where students are engaged in direct instruction, group work, or individual learning activities led by their teacher. This doesn't include lunch breaks, recess, or passing periods between classes. Regarding exceptions for educational purposes, our proposal allows teachers to grant permission for phone use during specific lessons or projects where devices are necessary tools. For example, if a math class needs calculators or a language arts project requires research online. Teachers will still have discretion to determine when phones can be used for legitimate academic reasons. speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Absolutely, Kate. Restorative practices are an essential part of our updated Student Code of Conduct. In essence, these approaches focus on repairing harm, building empathy, and promoting personal growth rather than simply punishing misbehavior. Imagine a circle conversation after a conflict, where students involved discuss how they were affected, take responsibility, and work together to find a resolution. Or, instead of detention, a student reflects on their actions and creates a plan to make amends.

To ensure consistency, we'll provide professional development opportunities for our educators and administrators throughout the year.
